Computer vision models have shown promise for efficient and automated plant disease identification, but there are limitations for real-world applications. These include variations in visual symptoms of a single disease, different light and weather conditions, and the complexity of the models. This work studies the performance of efficient classification models and training techniques to solve this problem, aiming to provide a plausible solution for ecological disasters and assist producers worldwide. More information is available at: https://github.com/mv-lab/mlplants

Introduction

Plant diseases affect crop production in both developed and developing countries, making rapid identification difficult, particularly in areas lacking necessary resources. This can lead to serious environmental disasters that severely impact the economy. To address this issue, we aim to develop a system that can process images captured in-situ in the field using a smartphone, due to the efficiency of the studied models.

Cassava (Manihot esculenta) is a key staple and food security crop in Africa, with at least 80% of household farms in Sub-Saharan Africa growing this starchy root. It is robust to adverse weather conditions and is the second-largest provider of carbohydrates in Africa. Several diseases plague the crop, causing annual yield losses valued at an estimated $20 million.

Accurate disease diagnostics require agricultural experts from government agencies to visually inspect the plants, making it difficult to effectively monitor and treat disease progression. In terms of value, apple (Malus domestica Borkh. 1803) is one of the most economically important fruit crops in the world, with annual losses of $15 billion. Apple production is heavily affected by a range of pests and diseases, including mites, aphids, stink bug, and European sawfly. Early and accurate disease detection is critical for management in orchards, as pesticide overuse has negative environmental impacts.

Recent advances in machine learning and computer vision, paired with universal and global access to smartphones, offer a clear path towards low-cost plant disease diagnosis in the wild. Although computer vision models have shown promising results for efficient plant disease detection, there are many factors that complicate the design of such a tool, including multiple diseases present in an image, small datasets, and noisy inputs (light and shade variations, non-uniform backgrounds).

Our contributions aim to tackle these challenges in the wild. We explore state-of-the-art models and regularization techniques to achieve a general and robust application, as illustrated in Figure 1.

Related Work

In recent years, multiple large-scale annotated datasets have been proposed for this topic. We will discuss the datasets in Section A. Kumar et al. presented the first mobile app ("Leafsnap") for identifying plant species using automatic visual recognition in 2012. Since 2016, deep learning and computer vision approaches have been used in many agriculture problems, including automated plant species identification and phenotyping, and plant pathology recognition. These approaches use Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs).

Mohanty et al. introduced the use of deep learning and CNNs for image-based plant disease detection using the "PlantVillage" dataset. More recently, Keaton et al. proposed a model for plant species identification using object detection as a form of attention. Existing computer vision research in categorization struggles with fine-grained attributes recognition due to the inherently high intra-class variance and low inter-class variance. The large variation in visual symptoms of a single disease class across different samples presents a major challenge for deep learning models.

This variation arises from differences in natural and image capturing environments, leaf color and morphology. Hence, models must be robust to environmental variation (i.e., viewpoints, light, background), and, due to the nature of the public large-scale datasets, the models should learn from noisy labels.

Datasets

Plant pathology researchers have collected real-world datasets with enough variability and size to train deep learning models. Images of disease symptoms on leaves were captured using smartphones at different distances and angles from the leaves, with different focus and light conditions to represent real-world scenarios.
